messages: 91b044d0543a76aae42a5100456ddbb7 (08:40): is there a way to turn off boldness when syntax hightlight is on?
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (08:57): hi Type gui=none | hi Statement gui=none
91b044d0543a76aae42a5100456ddbb7 (09:05): tried both .. didn't seem to work, tpope
74b03e84f75bc6733d3bccb926c69dd9 (09:07): (the file doesn't exist, but I didn't think it had to)
74b03e84f75bc6733d3bccb926c69dd9 (09:07): the path exists, but tnot the file itself
74b03e84f75bc6733d3bccb926c69dd9 (09:07): I'm just doing a path with nothing at the beginning
74b03e84f75bc6733d3bccb926c69dd9 (09:07): assuming it will take my current directory
74b03e84f75bc6733d3bccb926c69dd9 (09:08): is it supposed to work with the current dir?
91b044d0543a76aae42a5100456ddbb7 (09:08): or :pwd to see where you are
91b044d0543a76aae42a5100456ddbb7 (09:09): it should but if the current path doesn't have directory/to then it will choke
74b03e84f75bc6733d3bccb926c69dd9 (09:09): ah.. it has me in my home dir
74b03e84f75bc6733d3bccb926c69dd9 (09:09): when I open gvim from nautilus
74b03e84f75bc6733d3bccb926c69dd9 (09:09): is it possible to make it cd to the directory that holds the file?
91b044d0543a76aae42a5100456ddbb7 (09:10): you can always do it on :cd path
74b03e84f75bc6733d3bccb926c69dd9 (09:11): cause when I open vim from a shell
74b03e84f75bc6733d3bccb926c69dd9 (09:11): it will automatically be in the right path
91b044d0543a76aae42a5100456ddbb7 (09:11): but it's better using absolute path
74b03e84f75bc6733d3bccb926c69dd9 (09:11): I was just wondering if there was a way to have it do that from nautilus
74b03e84f75bc6733d3bccb926c69dd9 (09:11): cause this isn't the only problem
828997d3329f6368569d69d0d2baa3e6 (09:11): charles`: I have nautilus open files with a script that does: gvim -c "cd %:h" "$1"
91b044d0543a76aae42a5100456ddbb7 (09:13): is it possible to turn off automatic capitalized keywords with syntax highlight on? it's just too hard and ugly to read :)
74b03e84f75bc6733d3bccb926c69dd9 (09:14): frustrato, syntax highlighting on which language?
91b044d0543a76aae42a5100456ddbb7 (09:14): right now i'm looking at C++
91b044d0543a76aae42a5100456ddbb7 (09:14): but it goes with perl as well...really ugly and hard to read
74b03e84f75bc6733d3bccb926c69dd9 (09:15): I don't know, but on a lark I'd say something is totally broken
91b044d0543a76aae42a5100456ddbb7 (09:16): it works this way on fedora
91b044d0543a76aae42a5100456ddbb7 (09:17): i can manually set cterm for each of the groups, but it's painful and losing standout colors
828997d3329f6368569d69d0d2baa3e6 (09:18): frustrato: if you're using vim in console, gui=none doesn't do anything - use cterm=none
828997d3329f6368569d69d0d2baa3e6 (09:19): but in that case, cterm shouldn't do anything..
74b03e84f75bc6733d3bccb926c69dd9 (09:20): wait.. what is automatic capitalized words?
74b03e84f75bc6733d3bccb926c69dd9 (09:21): tpope, no I'm just wondering what frustrato is talking about.
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (09:21): so why did you say yes?
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (09:22): that mean no, it is console vim
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (09:22): and that means it is a terminal thing
91b044d0543a76aae42a5100456ddbb7 (09:23): the default one that comes with fc 5
828997d3329f6368569d69d0d2baa3e6 (09:23): frustrato: maybe you should just try the gui.
91b044d0543a76aae42a5100456ddbb7 (09:24): how can i use the gui?
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (09:25): probably in a menu somewhere too
91b044d0543a76aae42a5100456ddbb7 (09:26): oh boy .. doesn't look like gvim installed on the box
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (09:26): it will probably be worth your time to find it
74b03e84f75bc6733d3bccb926c69dd9 (09:26): frustrato, is it bolding stuff or capitalizing?
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (09:26): the package might be called vim-gtk or vim-gnome
74b03e84f75bc6733d3bccb926c69dd9 (09:27): he said 'is it possible to turn off automatic capitalized keywords with syntax highlight on? it's just too hard and ugly to read :)'
74b03e84f75bc6733d3bccb926c69dd9 (09:27): that's what was throwing me off
91b044d0543a76aae42a5100456ddbb7 (09:27): 4 coronas didn't do me any good
74b03e84f75bc6733d3bccb926c69dd9 (09:27): I was like wtf I've never seen that
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (09:27): charles` I didn't see that but it doesn't surprise me
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (09:30): frustrato: it didn't take me long to find it in the gnome-terminal settings, you can find it too
74b03e84f75bc6733d3bccb926c69dd9 (09:34): what's the syntax to do a search for an exact string?
fdd2857f7e10657ff26e8adae48cfb9c (09:34): How do you mean exact?
74b03e84f75bc6733d3bccb926c69dd9 (09:34): e.g. to quote the string so it doesn't go into regular expressions
fdd2857f7e10657ff26e8adae48cfb9c (09:34): oh, use \<word\>, \< ad \> are word boundaries
74b03e84f75bc6733d3bccb926c69dd9 (09:59): goflyapig, how exactly does your nautilus script work?
828997d3329f6368569d69d0d2baa3e6 (10:01): that's exactly what mine looks like.
828997d3329f6368569d69d0d2baa3e6 (10:01): what happens when you tell nautilus to use it to open something?

fdd2857f7e10657ff26e8adae48cfb9c (10:02): I have a file with windows line ends in it, my vimrc. When I start vim it ofcource errors, but When I try to remove them using :%s/^M// (ctrl-v ctrl-m) it says they arent there
74b03e84f75bc6733d3bccb926c69dd9 (10:02): goflyapig, I was trying it from the commandline first
74b03e84f75bc6733d3bccb926c69dd9 (10:05): goflyapig, is there an easy way I can globally change everything nautilus now uses gvim for to use the script instead?
828997d3329f6368569d69d0d2baa3e6 (10:07): hm, I dunno.  changing it on one text file seemed to do it for all of 'em for me
828997d3329f6368569d69d0d2baa3e6 (10:08): or maybe I'm imagining things because I just noticed nautilus isn't opening _anything_ with vim now :\
fdd2857f7e10657ff26e8adae48cfb9c (10:15): The fileformat is dos, hmm
